problem: What is the minimum value of $y$ if $y=3x^2+6x+9?$
solution: First, complete square as follows: $$y=3x^2+6x+9=3\left(x^2+2x\right)+9.$$ To complete the square, we need to add $\left(\frac{2}{2}\right)^2=1$ after the $2x.$ So we have $$y+3=3\left(x^2+2x+1\right)+9.$$ This gives $$y=3\left(x+1\right)^2+6.$$ Now, since $\left(x+1\right)^2\ge0,$ the minimum value is when the squared term is equal to $0.$ So the minimum value is $$y=3\left(x+1\right)^2+6=3\cdot0+6=\boxed{6}.$$
chatgpt_solution:
We can complete the square to find the minimum value of $y$. Shifting all the terms to the left side, we have \[\begin{aligned}y-9&=3x^2+6x\\ &=3\left(x^2+2x\right)\\ &=3\left(x^2+2x+1\right)-3\\ &=3\left(x+1\right)^2-3.\end{aligned}\]Since $3\left(x+1\right)^2\ge0$ for all values of $x,$ it follows that the minimum value of $y-9$ is $\boxed{-3}.$  We can achieve this value when $x = -1.$

Alternatively, note that $3x^2 + 6x + 9 = 3 (x + 1)^2 + 6,$ so the minimum value is $\boxed{6}.$
